001package io.github.ai4ci.config.inhost;
002
003import org.immutables.value.Value;
004
005import com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.annotation.JsonDeserialize;
006import com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.annotation.JsonSerialize;
007
008import io.github.ai4ci.abm.inhost.InHostStochasticState;
009import io.github.ai4ci.flow.builders.DefaultInHostStochasticStateInitialiser;
010import io.github.ai4ci.functions.Distribution;
011import io.github.ai4ci.functions.SimpleDistribution;
012import io.github.ai4ci.util.Sampler;
013
014/**
015 * Parameters for a stochastic in‑host viral dynamics model.
016 *
017 * <p>
018 * This interface defines the numerical inputs and distributions used to
019 * initialise the discrete stochastic in‑host model implemented by
020 * {@link InHostStochasticState}. Values here are sampled by the default
021 * initialiser {@link DefaultInHostStochasticStateInitialiser} to construct an
022 * initial {@code InHostStochasticState} for each infected individual. The
023 * parameters control initial pool sizes, immune capacity and activation
024 * dynamics, rates of viral replication and infection, and the calibration
025 * cutoff for what constitutes a disease‑level viral load.
026 *
027 * <p>
028 * Keep descriptions concise: the initialiser samples distributional entries
029 * (see methods returning {@link Distribution}) and copies scalar parameters
030 * directly into the initial in‑host state. Downstream updates are performed by
031 * {@link InHostStochasticState#update(Sampler,double,double)} which uses these
032 * initial values to govern stochastic transitions.
033 *
034 * @author Rob Challen
035 */
036@Value.Immutable
037@JsonSerialize(as = ImmutableStochasticModel.class)
038@JsonDeserialize(as = ImmutableStochasticModel.class)
039public interface StochasticModel extends InHostConfiguration {
040
041        /**
042         * A sensible default configuration for the stochastic in‑host model.
043         *
044         * <p>
045         * This instance provides default distributions and scalars used in examples
046         * and tests. The {@link DefaultInHostStochasticStateInitialiser} will sample
047         * the distributional entries from this object when creating a fresh
048         * {@link InHostStochasticState}.
049         */
050        public static ImmutableStochasticModel DEFAULT = ImmutableStochasticModel
051                        .builder().setTargetCellCount(10000)
052                        .setImmuneTargetRatio(SimpleDistribution.logNorm(1D, 0.1))
053                        .setImmuneActivationRate(SimpleDistribution.logNorm(1D, 0.1))
054                        .setImmuneWaningRate(SimpleDistribution.logNorm(1D / 150, 0.01))
055                        .setInfectionCarrierProbability(SimpleDistribution.point(0D))
056                        .setTargetRecoveryRate(SimpleDistribution.logNorm(1D / 7, 0.1))
057                        .setBaselineViralInfectionRate(1D).setBaselineViralReplicationRate(4D)
058                        .setVirionsDiseaseCutoff(1000)
059                        // .setTargetSymptomsCutoff( 0.2 )
060                        .build();
061
062        /**
063         * Baseline per‑virion infection rate used to calibrate the infection
064         * probability.
065         *
066         * <p>
067         * The scalar is copied into the initial in‑host state. It is converted into
068         * a per‑time‑step probability during updates and therefore directly affects
069         * how readily virions convert susceptible targets into exposed cells in
070         * {@link InHostStochasticState#update(Sampler, double, double)}.
071         *
072         * @return baseline viral infection rate (scalar)
073         */
074        Double getBaselineViralInfectionRate();
075
076        /**
077         * Baseline viral replication rate used to determine virion production.
078         *
079         * <p>
080         * This scalar sets the expected production per infected cell and is
081         * sampled/copied by the initialiser into the host state. Larger values
082         * increase the expected Poisson rate of new virions produced each step,
083         * driving faster viral load growth.
084         *
085         * @return baseline viral replication rate (scalar)
086         */
087        Double getBaselineViralReplicationRate();
088
089        /**
090         * Distribution for the immune activation (priming) rate.
091         *
092         * <p>
093         * This distribution is sampled by the initialiser to set the host's
094         * propensity to prime immune cells in response to exposed or infected
095         * targets. A higher sampled value leads to faster priming and earlier immune
096         * activity during {@code InHostStochasticState.update}.
097         *
098         * @return a distribution for immune priming rates
099         */
100        Distribution getImmuneActivationRate();
101
102        /**
103         * Distribution for the immune to target cell ratio.
104         *
105         * <p>
106         * The initialiser samples this distribution to set the starting total immune
107         * count via floor(targets * ratio). This controls immune capacity relative
108         * to target cells and influences neutralisation and clearance probabilities
109         * in subsequent stochastic updates.
110         *
111         * @return a distribution producing immune:target ratios used at
112         *         initialisation
113         */
114        Distribution getImmuneTargetRatio();
115
116        /**
117         * Distribution for the waning rate of active immune cells.
118         *
119         * <p>
120         * The initialiser samples this entry to determine how quickly active
121         * effectors transition to senescent states. Faster waning reduces long‑ term
122         * immune activity and can increase susceptibility to reinfection in the
123         * simulation.
124         *
125         * @return a distribution for immune waning rates
126         */
127        Distribution getImmuneWaningRate();
128
129        /**
130         * Distribution giving the probability an exposed cell becomes a chronic
131         * carrier.
132         *
133         * <p>
134         * Sampled at initialisation, this controls the per‑cell probability that an
135         * exposed target will evade clearance and enter a persistent reservoir. Even
136         * if the default is zero, non‑zero values alter long‑term infection dynamics
137         * and the pool of targets available for future replication.
138         *
139         * @return a distribution for chronic infection carrier probability
140         */
141        Distribution getInfectionCarrierProbability();
142
143        /**
144         * Total number of target cells modelled for a single host.
145         *
146         * <p>
147         * The initialiser places this value into the created
148         * {@link InHostStochasticState} as both the total target pool and the
149         * initial susceptible pool. It therefore sets the scale of the infection:
150         * larger pools reduce per‑cell exposure for a given number of virions and
151         * change the saturation behaviour in the coverage calculations used during
152         * infection updates.
153         *
154         * @return the initial total target cell count
155         */
156        Integer getTargetCellCount();
157
158        /**
159         * Distribution for the target cell recovery (regeneration) rate.
160         *
161         * <p>
162         * The initialiser samples this distribution to set the baseline rate at
163         * which removed or damaged targets are replaced. Higher recovery rates
164         * replenish susceptible targets more quickly and can shorten the period of
165         * high severity in the in‑host simulation.
166         *
167         * @return a distribution for target recovery rates used at initialisation
168         */
169        Distribution getTargetRecoveryRate();
170
171        /**
172         * Calibration parameter defining the unit of virions considered
173         * disease‑level.
174         *
175         * <p>
176         * The initialiser stores this cutoff on the host state; it is used to
177         * normalise virion counts into a unitless viral load proxy and to scale
178         * external virion doses. Changing this value moves the threshold for when an
179         * individual's viral load is treated as clinically relevant in the
180         * simulation.
181         *
182         * @return the virion disease cutoff used for normalisation and dosing
183         */
184        Integer getVirionsDiseaseCutoff();
185
186}
